rename.from: ci and development: much more effective testing via pytest-testmon

body:
> ... <1000 instead of >20000?? 👀 👀 👀 👁️‍👁️‍

I put my testing commits to this table. I've been triggering the runs and writing the table by hand, so sometimes the durations and links are not apples to apples comparisons.  However as you can see this is great. 
More random thoughts: 
* I might have been lucky, with the commits I picked, it's not a big sample size. However it's quite time consuming to do this so I would like to have your decision about --pyargs, before investing more time into this.
* `python -m pytest sktime/` picks **20633** tests vs **20212** picked by `pytest --pyargs sktime`. (I'm sure this could be fixed in pytest conf to match perfectly)
* creating virtualenv takes 3 minutes. I used https://github.com/marketplace/actions/restore-or-create-a-python-virtualenv 
* execution of 0 or 1 test takes ~ 3 minutes. As far as I know this is not overhead of testmon but initialization of sktime. 
* there is huge amount of warnings which makes it quite annoying to work with the logs.

Watch out, the table is probably wider then you see.

| testmon                                                                                                                                              |               |       | original                                                                                                                                                                           |               |       |
| ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------- | ----- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------- | ----- |
| link                                                                                                                                                 | duration in m | tests | link                                                                                                                                                                               | duration in m | tests |
| [https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/runs/5784944422?check\_suite\_focus=true](https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/runs/5784944422?check_suite_focus=true) | 3.5           | 0     | [https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/5705928653?check\_suite\_focus=true](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/5705928653?check_suite_focus=true) | 39            | 20211 |
| [https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/actions/runs/2076198991](https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/actions/runs/2076198991)                                 | 10            | 1778  | [https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/5711518763?check\_suite\_focus=true](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/5711518763?check_suite_focus=true) | 40            | 20202 |
| [https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/runs/5785681379?check\_suite\_focus=true](https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/runs/5785681379?check_suite_focus=true) | 7             | 110   | [https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/5711858176?check\_suite\_focus=true](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/5711858176?check_suite_focus=true) | 45            | 20213 |
| [https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/runs/5785827784?check\_suite\_focus=true](https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/runs/5785827784?check_suite_focus=true) | 3.5           | 4     | [https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/5712043068?check\_suite\_focus=true](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/5712043068?check_suite_focus=true) | 60.5          | 20212 |
| [https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/actions/runs/2076560534](https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/actions/runs/2076560534)                                 | 12.5          | 1779  | [https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/5712267222?check\_suite\_focus=true](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/5712267222?check_suite_focus=true) | 60.5          | 20212 |
| [https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/actions/runs/2076658605](https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/actions/runs/2076658605)                                 | 3.5           | 1     | [https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/5712506663?check\_suite\_focus=true](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/5712506663?check_suite_focus=true) | 44            | 20k   |
| [https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/actions/runs/2076758669](https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/actions/runs/2076758669)                                 | 10            | 1779  | [https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/5712509879?check\_suite\_focus=true](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/5712509879?check_suite_focus=true) | 43            | 20k   |
| [https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/actions/runs/2076855145](https://github.com/tarpas/sktime/actions/runs/2076855145)                                 | 56            | 20633 | [https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/actions/runs/2074016337](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/actions/runs/2074016337)                                 | 52            | 20212  |

@tarpas, this looks nice!

Here's a question: could you kindly explain the logic picking the tests in the following simplified case?

* there is a function `get_all_classes` that picks up all classes in `sktime` and feeds them to three tests via `pytest_generate_tests`, let's say `test1`, `test2`, `test3`, depending on properties of the class (let's say attributes `needs_test1`, `needs_test2`, `needs_test3`)
* in PR no.1, we add one new class somewhere in `sktime`
* in PR no.2, we change the `needs_test2` attribute to `True` from `False` in some existing class

Based on the "lines affected" logic (which I think is behind `testmon`?), why would this pick the right tests, i.e., in PR no.1 whichever tests the attributes require (optimally only on the new class), and in test no.2, exactly `test2` (optimally, only on the changed class)?

(this is simplified from how the `sktime` test suite actually works, there is no `get_all_classes`, but there is `all_estimators` which is used inside `BaseFixtureGenerator.pytest_generate_tests` via `create_conditional_fixtures_and_names`)

Maybe the parameter of the test changes? test2[Class1] -> test2[Class2] ? In that case the node_id of the test changes and the "new" node_id is executed. If that's not the case, testmon will probably miss the change :(

There is actually much simpler case where I'm struggling for solution. If a constant from a different module (e.g. `consts`) is used in a test, e.g. 
```python
import consts
def test_a_is_1:
    assert consts.A == 1
```
the change of `A` value would be missed. I think I saw a commit in sktime a couple of weeks ago which concentrates the result values to be asserted into a different module, creating exactly this situation.

What now? :)

My suggestion regarding sktime testing holds. I would like you to test editable (git) source in CI. If somebody could also work on the inherent problems of the suite (long initialization and kilobytes of warnings), that would be great. If that's done I'll try to test testmon with sktime, compare the results and come up with sensible solutions/suggestions.

> What now? :)

I´m not sure - could you give a few lines of why this would be missed?

> If somebody could also work on the inherent problems of the suite (long initialization and kilobytes of warnings), that would be great.

Long initialization is due to fixture collection - any ideas how to address that?

Warnings are mostly deprecation related, is that correct?

> > What now? :)
> 
> I´m not sure - could you give a few lines of why this would be missed?

testmon considers only lines executed during the test execution as dependencies. Lines which are executed at import time (before test execution) are only considered a dependency in some cases and the case described is not one of them. I already have a couple of ideas how to approach fixing this, but it's not easy and without runtime cost.

> 
> Long initialization is due to fixture collection - any ideas how to address that?

pytest doesn't create fixtures for deselected tests. Are the many different classes initialized during pytest_generate_tests by chance? Would it be possible to postpone that to test setup? Maybe there is not low hanging fruit :/

> 
> Warnings are mostly deprecation related, is that correct?

It seems so. If not fixing, then maybe supressing warnings would be OK?

To modify and reiterate  my suggestion.
* sktime would test editable (git) source in CI (no --pyargs)
* `--tmnet-noselect` would be used so that no data is skipped, just ordered with the most likely to fail executing first 
* data would be collected, to understand if testmon would skip any failures
* later if everything looks good, `--tmnet-noselect --maxfail=1` can be used to save time of execution and capacity of CI, but not skip a failure
* then --tmnet can be switched on for PRs
* then --tmnet can be switched on in full

issue.title: [MNT] Cut down test time to under 10 min

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
<!--
A clear and concise description of what the bug is.
-->

The current testing suite is horrendously long and creates a poor developer experience with the test suite taking ~1h to complete.

body: I'm on it!. I released a version tmnet/testmon which sorts tests as promised (--tmnet-noselect didn't sort them before). Now I discovered some new bug. sktime si quite a beast but I hope to have a PR read in the upcoming days.

> sktime is quite a beast

😅 I hope you mean this only in the best possible of ways 😁 

Jokes aside, thanks a lot for looking into this!
@fkiraly I discovered a couple of new compatibility and performance problems and a memory leak since I tested sktime months ago. I'm working on it, but it will take time (~ weeks)
